play.title: The History of Troilus and Cressida

speech.speaker: PROLOGUE.
speech.line: In Troy, there lies the scene. From isles of Greece
The princes orgulous, their high blood chaf’d,
Have to the port of Athens sent their ships
Fraught with the ministers and instruments
Of cruel war. Sixty and nine, that wore
Their crownets regal, from th’ Athenian bay
Put forth toward Phrygia, and their vow is made
To ransack Troy, within whose strong immures
The ravish’d Helen, Menelaus’ queen,
With wanton Paris sleeps—and that’s the quarrel.
To Tenedos they come,
And the deep-drawing barks do there disgorge
Their warlike fraughtage. Now on Dardan plains
The fresh and yet unbruised Greeks do pitch
Their brave pavilions. Priam’s six-gated city,
Dardan and Timbria, Helias, Chetas, Troien,
And Antenorides, with massy staples
And corresponsive and fulfilling bolts
Sperr up the sons of Troy.
Now expectation, tickling skittish spirits,
On one and other side, Troyan and Greek,
Sets all on hazard—and hither am I come,
A prologue arm’d, but not in confidence
Of author’s pen or actor’s voice, but suited
In like conditions as our argument,
To tell you, fair beholders, that our play
Leaps o’er the vaunt and firstlings of those broils,
Beginning in the middle; starting thence away
To what may be digested in a play.
Like or find fault, do as your pleasures are,
Now good or bad, ’tis but the chance of war.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Peace, you ungracious clamors! Peace, rude sounds!
Fools on both sides, Helen must needs be fair,
When with your blood you daily paint her thus.
I cannot fight upon this argument;
It is too starv’d a subject for my sword.
But Pandarus—O gods! How do you plague me!
I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar,
And he’s as tetchy to be woo’d to woo,
As she is stubborn-chaste against all suit.
Tell me, Apollo, for thy Daphne’s love,
What Cressid is, what Pandar, and what we:
Her bed is India, there she lies, a pearl;
Between our Ilium and where she resides,
Let it be call’d the wild and wand’ring flood,
Ourself the merchant, and this sailing Pandar
Our doubtful hope, our convoy, and our bark.

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: Hark what good sport is out of town today.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Better at home, if “would I might” were “may.”
But to the sport abroad—are you bound thither?

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: In all swift haste.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Come go we then together.

stagedir.dir: Enter Cressida and her man Alexander.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Who comes here?

speech.speaker: ALEX.
speech.line: Madam, your uncle Pandarus.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Hector’s a gallant man.

speech.speaker: ALEX.
speech.line: As may be in the world, lady.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: What’s that? What’s that?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Good morrow, uncle Pandarus.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Good morrow, cousin Cressid. What do you talk of? Good morrow, Alexander. How do you, cousin? When were you at Ilium?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: This morning, uncle.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: What were you talking of when I came? Was Hector arm’d and gone ere ye came to Ilium? Helen was not up, was she?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Hector was gone, but Helen was not up.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: E’en so; Hector was stirring early.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: That were we talking of, and of his anger.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Was he angry?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: So he says here.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: True, he was so; I know the cause too. He’ll lay about him today, I can tell them that, and there’s Troilus will not come far behind him. Let them take heed of Troilus; I can tell them that too.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: What, is he angry too?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Who, Troilus? Troilus is the better man of the two.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: O Jupiter, there’s no comparison.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: What, not between Troilus and Hector? Do you know a man if you see him?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Ay, if I ever saw him before and knew him.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Well, I say Troilus is Troilus.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Then you say as I say, for I am sure he is not Hector.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: No, nor Hector is not Troilus in some degrees.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: ’Tis just to each of them; he is himself.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Himself? Alas, poor Troilus, I would he were!

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: So he is.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Condition I had gone barefoot to India.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: He is not Hector.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Himself? No! He’s not himself. Would ’a were himself! Well, the gods are above, time must friend or end. Well, Troilus, well, I would my heart were in her body. No, Hector is not a better man than Troilus.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Excuse me.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: He is elder.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Pardon me, pardon me.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Th’ other’s not come to’t. You shall tell me another tale when th’ other’s come to’t. Hector shall not have his wit this year.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: He shall not need it if he have his own.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Nor his qualities.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: No matter.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Nor his beauty.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: ’Twould not become him, his own’s better.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: You have no judgment, niece. Helen herself swore th’ other day that Troilus, for a brown favor (for so ’tis, I must confess)—not brown neither—

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: No, but brown.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Faith, to say truth, brown and not brown.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: To say the truth, true and not true.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: She prais’d his complexion above Paris.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Why, Paris hath color enough.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: So he has.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Then Troilus should have too much: if she prais’d him above, his complexion is higher than his. He having color enough, and the other higher, is too flaming a praise for a good complexion. I had as lieve Helen’s golden tongue had commended Troilus for a copper nose.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: I swear to you, I think Helen loves him better than Paris.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Then she’s a merry Greek indeed.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Nay, I am sure she does. She came to him th’ other day into the compass’d window—and you know he has not past three or four hairs on his chin—

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Indeed a tapster’s arithmetic may soon bring his particulars therein to a total.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Why, he is very young, and yet will he, within three pound, lift as much as his brother Hector.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Is he so young a man and so old a lifter?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: But to prove to you that Helen loves him: she came and puts me her white hand to his cloven chin—

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Juno have mercy! How came it cloven?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Why, you know ’tis dimpled. I think his smiling becomes him better than any man in all Phrygia.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: O, he smiles valiantly.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Does he not?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: O yes, and ’twere a cloud in autumn.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Why, go to then. But to prove to you that Helen loves Troilus—

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Troilus will stand to the proof, if you’ll prove it so.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Troilus! Why, he esteems her no more than I esteem an addle egg.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: If you love an addle egg as well as you love an idle head, you would eat chickens i’ th’ shell.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: I cannot choose but laugh to think how she tickled his chin. Indeed she has a marvell’s white hand, I must needs confess.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Without the rack.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: And she takes upon her to spy a white hair on his chin.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Alas, poor chin! Many a wart is richer.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: But there was such laughing! Queen Hecuba laugh’d that her eyes ran o’er.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: With millstones.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: And Cassandra laugh’d.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: But there was a more temperate fire under the pot of her eyes. Did her eyes run o’er too?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: And Hector laugh’d.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: At what was all this laughing?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Marry, at the white hair that Helen spied on Troilus’ chin.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: And’t had been a green hair, I should have laugh’d too.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: They laugh’d not so much at the hair as at his pretty answer.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: What was his answer?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Quoth she, “Here’s but two and fifty hairs on your chin—and one of them is white.”

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: This is her question.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: That’s true, make no question of that. “Two and fifty hairs,” quoth he, “and one white. That white hair is my father, and all the rest are his sons.” “Jupiter,” quoth she, “which of these hairs is Paris my husband?” “The fork’d one,” quoth he, “pluck’t out, and give it him.” But there was such laughing! And Helen so blush’d, and Paris so chaf’d, and all the rest so laugh’d, that it pass’d.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: So let it now, for it has been a great while going by.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Well, cousin, I told you a thing yesterday, think on’t.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: So I do.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: I’ll be sworn ’tis true; he will weep you an’ ’twere a man born in April.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Speak not so loud.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: That’s Aeneas; is not that a brave man? He’s one of the flowers of Troy, I can tell you. But mark Troilus; you shall see anon.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Who’s that?

stagedir.dir: Enter Antenor and passes over the stage.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: That’s Hector, that, that, look you, that; there’s a fellow! Go thy way. Hector! There’s a brave man, niece. O brave Hector! Look how he looks! There’s a countenance! Is’t not a brave man?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: O, a brave man!

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Is ’a not? It does a man’s heart good. Look you what hacks are on his helmet! Look you yonder, do you see? Look you there, there’s no jesting; there’s laying on, take’t off who will, as they say. There be hacks!

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Be those with swords?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Swords! Any thing, he cares not; and the devil come to him, it’s all one. By God’s lid, it does one’s heart good. Yonder comes Paris, yonder comes Paris.

stagedir.dir: Enter Paris and passes over the stage.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: That’s Helenus. I marvel where Troilus is. That’s Helenus. I think he went not forth today. That’s Helenus.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Can Helenus fight, uncle?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Helenus? No. Yes, he’ll fight indifferent well. I marvel where Troilus is. Hark, do you not hear the people cry “Troilus”? Helenus is a priest.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: What sneaking fellow comes yonder?

stagedir.dir: Enter Troilus and passes over the stage.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Here comes more.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Asses, fools, dolts! Chaff and bran, chaff and bran! Porridge after meat! I could live and die in the eyes of Troilus. Ne’er look, ne’er look, the eagles are gone; crows and daws, crows and daws! I had rather be such a man as Troilus than Agamemnon and all Greece.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: There is amongst the Greeks Achilles, a better man than Troilus.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Achilles! A drayman, a porter, a very camel.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Well, well,

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Well, well! Why, have you any discretion? Have you any eyes? Do you know what a man is? Is not birth, beauty, good shape, discourse, manhood, learning, gentleness, virtue, youth, liberality, and suchlike, the spice and salt that season a man?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Ay, a minc’d man, and then to be bak’d with no date in the pie, for then the man’s date is out.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: You are such a woman, a man knows not at what ward you lie.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Upon my back, to defend my belly, upon my wit, to defend my wiles, upon my secrecy, to defend mine honesty, my mask, to defend my beauty, and you, to defend all these; and at all these wards I lie, at a thousand watches.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Say one of your watches.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Nay, I’ll watch you for that; and that’s one of the chiefest of them too. If I cannot ward what I would not have hit, I can watch you for telling how I took the blow—unless it swell past hiding, and then it’s past watching.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: You are such another!
I doubt he be hurt. Fare ye well, good niece.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Adieu, uncle.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: I will be with you, niece, by and by.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: To bring, uncle?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Ay, a token from Troilus.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: By the same token, you are a bawd.

scene.scenelocation: The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon’s tent.

stagedir.dir: Sennet. Enter Agamemnon, Nestor, Ulysses, Diomedes, Menelaus, with others.

scene.line: most mighty for thy place and sway,

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: What trumpet? Look, Menelaus.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: From Troy.

scene.line: We have, great Agamemnon, here in Troy
A prince call’d Hector—Priam is his father—
Who in this dull and long-continued truce
Is resty grown. He bade me take a trumpet,
And to this purpose speak: kings, princes, lords!
If there be one among the fair’st of Greece
That holds his honor higher than his ease,
And seeks his praise more than he fears his peril,
That knows his valor, and knows not his fear,
That loves his mistress more than in confession
With truant vows to her own lips he loves,
And dare avow her beauty and her worth
In other arms than hers—to him this challenge!
Hector, in view of Troyans and of Greeks,
Shall make it good, or do his best to do it:
He hath a lady, wiser, fairer, truer,
Than ever Greek did couple in his arms,
And will tomorrow with his trumpet call,
Midway between your tents and walls of Troy,
To rouse a Grecian that is true in love.
If any come, Hector shall honor him;
If none, he’ll say in Troy when he retires,
The Grecian dames are sunburnt, and not worth
The splinter of a lance. Even so much.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: This shall be told our lovers, Lord Aeneas.
If none of them have soul in such a kind,
We left them all at home. But we are soldiers,
And may that soldier a mere recreant prove,
That means not, hath not, or is not in love!
If then one is, or hath, or means to be,
That one meets Hector; if none else, I am he.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: Tell him of Nestor, one that was a man
When Hector’s grandsire suck’d. He is old now,
But if there be not in our Grecian mould
A noble man that hath no spark of fire
To answer for his love, tell him from me
I’ll hide my silver beard in a gold beaver,
And in my vambrace put my withered brawns,
And meeting him will tell him that my lady
Was fairer than his grandam, and as chaste
As may be in the world. His youth in flood,
I’ll prove this troth with my three drops of blood.

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: Now heavens forfend such scarcity of youth!

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: Fair Lord Aeneas, let me touch your hand;
To our pavilion shall I lead you, sir,
Achilles shall have word of this intent,
So shall each lord of Greece, from tent to tent.
Yourself shall feast with us before you go,
And find the welcome of a noble foe.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: Thersites!

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Agamemnon, how if he had biles—full, all over, generally?

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: Thersites!

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: And those biles did run—say so—did not the general run then? Were not that a botchy core?

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: Dog!

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Then would come some matter from him; I see none now.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: Thou bitch-wolf’s son, canst thou not hear? Feel then.

scene.line: You whoreson cur!

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Do! Do! Thou stool for a witch! Ay, do! Do! Thou sodden-witted lord! Thou hast no more brain than I have in mine elbows, an asinico may tutor thee. You scurvy valiant ass! Thou art here but to thrash Troyans, and thou art bought and sold among those of any wit, like a barbarian slave. If thou use to beat me, I will begin at thy heel, and tell what thou art by inches, thou thing of no bowels, thou!

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: You dog!

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: You scurvy lord!

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Why, how now, Ajax, wherefore do ye thus?
How now, Thersites, what’s the matter, man?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: You see him there? Do you?

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Ay, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Nay, look upon him.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: So I do. What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Nay, but regard him well.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Well? Why, so I do.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: But yet you look not well upon him, for whosomever you take him to be, he is Ajax.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: I know that, fool.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Ay, but that fool knows not himself.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: Therefore I beat thee.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he utters! His evasions have ears thus long. I have bobb’d his brain more than he has beat my bones. I will buy nine sparrows for a penny, and his pia mater is not worth the ninth part of a sparrow. This lord, Achilles, Ajax, who wears his wit in his belly and his guts in his head, I’ll tell you what I say of him.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: I say, this Ajax—

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: A good riddance.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Marry, this, sir, is proclaim’d through all our host:
That Hector, by the fift hour of the sun,
Will with a trumpet ’twixt our tents and Troy
Tomorrow morning call some knight to arms
That hath a stomach, and such a one that dare
Maintain—I know not what, ’tis trash. Farewell.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: Farewell. Who shall answer him?

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: I know not, ’tis put to lott’ry. Otherwise,
He knew his man.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: O, meaning you? I will go learn more of it.

scene.scenelocation: Troy. A room in Priam’s palace.

stagedir.dir: Enter Priam, Hector, Troilus, Paris, and Helenus.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Cry, Troyans, cry! Lend me ten thousand eyes,
And I will fill them with prophetic tears.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Peace, sister, peace!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Virgins and boys, mid-age and wrinkled eld,
Soft infancy, that nothing canst but cry,
Add to my clamors! Let us pay betimes
A moi’ty of that mass of moan to come.
Cry, Troyans, cry! Practice your eyes with tears!
Troy must not be, nor goodly Ilion stand.
Our fire-brand brother Paris burns us all.
Cry, Troyans, cry! A Helen and a woe!
Cry, cry! Troy burns, or else let Helen go.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: How now, Thersites? What, lost in the labyrinth of thy fury? Shall the elephant Ajax carry it thus? He beats me, and I rail at him. O worthy satisfaction! Would it were otherwise: that I could beat him, whilst he rail’d at me. ’Sfoot, I’ll learn to conjure and raise devils, but I’ll see some issue of my spiteful execrations. Then there’s Achilles, a rare enginer! If Troy be not taken till these two undermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of themselves. O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus, forget that thou art Jove, the king of gods, and, Mercury, lose all the serpentine craft of thy caduceus, if ye take not that little little less than little wit from them that they have, which short-arm’d ignorance itself knows is so abundant scarce, it will not in circumvention deliver a fly from a spider, without drawing their massy irons and cutting the web! After this, the vengeance on the whole camp! Or rather, the Neapolitan bone-ache! For that methinks is the curse depending on those that war for a placket. I have said my prayers, and devil Envy say amen. What ho! My Lord Achilles!

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: Who’s there? Thersites? Good Thersites, come in and rail.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: If I could ’a’ rememb’red a gilt counterfeit, thou wouldst not have slipp’d out of my contemplation. But it is no matter, thyself upon thyself! The common curse of mankind, folly and ignorance, be thine in great revenue! Heaven bless thee from a tutor, and discipline come not near thee! Lee thy blood be thy direction till thy death; then if she that lays thee out says thou art a fair corse, I’ll be sworn and sworn upon’t she never shrouded any but lazars. Amen.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: Thersites, my lord.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Where? Where? O, where? Art thou come? Why, my cheese, my digestion, why hast thou not serv’d thyself in to my table so many meals? Come, what’s Agamemnon?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Thy commander, Achilles. Then tell me, Patroclus, what’s Achilles?

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: Thy lord, Thersites. Then tell me, I pray thee, what’s Thersites?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Thy knower, Patroclus. Then tell me, Patroclus, what art thou?

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: Thou must tell that knowest.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: O, tell, tell.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: I’ll decline the whole question: Agamemnon commands Achilles, Achilles is my lord, I am Patroclus’ knower, and Patroclus is a fool.

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: You rascal!

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Peace, fool, I have not done.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: He is a privileg’d man. Proceed, Thersites.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Agamemnon is a fool, Achilles is a fool, Thersites is a fool, and, as aforesaid, Patroclus is a fool.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Derive this; come.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Agamemnon is a fool to offer to command Achilles, Achilles is a fool to be commanded of Agamemnon, Thersites is a fool to serve such a fool, and this Patroclus is a fool positive.

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: Why am I a fool?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Make that demand of the prover, it suffices me thou art. Look you, who comes here?

stagedir.dir: Enter Agamemnon, Ulysses, Nestor, Diomedes, Ajax, and Calchas.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Here is such patchery, such juggling, and such knavery! All the argument is a whore and a cuckold, a good quarrel to draw emulous factions and bleed to death upon. Now the dry suppeago on the subject, and war and lechery confound all!

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: We saw him at the opening of his tent,
He is not sick.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: Yes, lion-sick, sick of proud heart. You may call it melancholy, if you will favor the man; but by my head, ’tis pride. But why, why? Let him show us a cause. A word, my lord.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: What moves Ajax thus to bay at him?

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Achilles hath inveigled his fool from him.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: Who, Thersites?

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: He.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: Then will Ajax lack matter, if he have lost his argument.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: No, you see he is his argument that has his argument, Achilles.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: All the better, their fraction is more our wish than their faction. But it was a strong composure a fool could disunite.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily untie.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: In second voice we’ll not be satisfied,
We come to speak with him. Ulysses, enter you.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: I do hate a proud man, as I do hate the engend’ring of toads.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: And yet he loves himself. Is’t not strange?

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Achilles will not to the field tomorrow.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: What’s his excuse?

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: He doth rely on none,
But carries on the stream of his dispose
Without observance or respect of any,
In will peculiar and in self-admission.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: Why will he not upon our fair request
Untent his person and share th’ air with us?

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Things small as nothing, for request’s sake only,
He makes important. Possess’d he is with greatness,
And speaks not to himself but with a pride
That quarrels at self-breath. Imagin’d worth
Holds in his blood such swoll’n and hot discourse
That ’twixt his mental and his active parts
Kingdom’d Achilles in commotion rages,
And batters down himself. What should I say?
He is so plaguy proud that the death-tokens of it
Cry “No recovery.”

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: Let Ajax go to him.
Dear lord, go you and greet him in his tent.
’Tis said he holds you well, and will be led
At your request a little from himself.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: O Agamemnon, let it not be so!
We’ll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes
When they go from Achilles. Shall the proud lord
That bastes his arrogance with his own seam,
And never suffers matter of the world
Enter his thoughts, save such as doth revolve
And ruminate himself, shall he be worshipp’d
Of that we hold an idol more than he?
No! This thrice worthy and right valiant lord
Shall not so stale his palm, nobly acquir’d,
Nor, by my will, assubjugate his merit,
As amply titled as Achilles’ is,
By going to Achilles.
That were to enlard his fat-already pride,
And add more coals to Cancer when he burns
With entertaining great Hyperion.
This lord go to him! Jupiter forbid,
And say in thunder, “Achilles go to him.”

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: O, this is well. He rubs the vein of him.

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: And how his silence drinks up his applause!

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: If I go to him, with my armed fist
I’ll pash him o’er the face.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: O no, you shall not go.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: And he be proud with me, I’ll pheese his pride.
Let me go to him.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: A paltry, insolent fellow!

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: How he describes himself!

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: Can he not be sociable?

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: The raven chides blackness.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: I’ll let his humors blood.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: He will be the physician that should be the patient.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: And all men were of my mind—

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Wit would be out of fashion.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: ’A should not bear it so, ’a should eat swords first. Shall pride carry it?

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: And ’twould, you’d carry half.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: ’A would have ten shares. I will knead him, I’ll make him supple. He’s not yet through warm.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: Force him with praises—pour in, pour in, his ambition is dry.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
PAN.
speech.line: Friend, you! Pray you a word. Do you not follow the young Lord Paris?

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: Ay, sir, when he goes before me.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: You depend upon him, I mean.

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: Sir, I do depend upon the Lord.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: You depend upon a notable gentleman; I must needs praise him.

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: The Lord be prais’d!

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: You know me, do you not?

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: Faith, sir, superficially.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Friend, know me better, I am the Lord Pandarus.

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: I hope I shall know your honor better!

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: I do desire it.

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: You are in the state of grace.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Grace? Not so, friend, honor and lordship are my titles. What music is this?

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: I do but partly know, sir, it is music in parts.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Know you the musicians?

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: Wholly, sir.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Who play they to?

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: To the hearers, sir.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: At whose pleasure, friend?

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: At mine, sir, and theirs that love music.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Command, I mean, friend.

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: Who shall I command, sir?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Friend, we understand not one another; I am too courtly and thou too cunning. At whose request do these men play?

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: That’s to’t indeed, sir. Marry, sir, at the request of Paris my lord, who is there in person; with him, the mortal Venus, the heart-blood of beauty, love’s invisible soul.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Who? My cousin Cressida?

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: No, sir, Helen. Could not you find out that by her attributes?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: It should seem, fellow, thou hast not seen the Lady Cressid. I come to speak with Paris from the Prince Troilus. I will make a complimental assault upon him, for my business seethes.

speech.speaker: PAR. SERV.
speech.line: Sodden business! There’s a stew’d phrase indeed!
“Love, love, nothing but love, still love, still more!
For O, love’s bow
Shoots buck and doe.
The shaft confounds
Not that it wounds,
But tickles still the sore.
These lovers cry, O ho, they die!
Yet that which seems the wound to kill,
Doth turn O ho! To ha, ha, he!
So dying love lives still.
O ho! A while, but ha, ha, ha!
O ho! Groans out for ha, ha, ha!—hey ho!”

speech.speaker: HELEN.
speech.line: In love, i’ faith, to the very tip of the nose.

speech.speaker: PAR.
speech.line: He eats nothing but doves, love, and that breeds hot blood, and hot blood begets hot thoughts, and hot thoughts beget hot deeds, and hot deeds is love.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Is this the generation of love—hot blood, hot thoughts, and hot deeds? Why, they are vipers. Is love a generation of vipers? Sweet lord, who’s a-field today?

speech.speaker: PAR.
speech.line: Hector, Deiphobus, Helenus, Antenor, and all the gallantry of Troy. I would fain have arm’d today, but my Nell would not have it so. How chance my brother Troilus went not?

speech.speaker: HELEN.
speech.line: He hangs the lip at something. You know all, Lord Pandarus.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Not I, honey-sweet queen. I long to hear how they sped today. You’ll remember your brother’s excuse?

speech.speaker: PAR.
speech.line: To a hair.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Farewell, sweet queen.

speech.speaker: HELEN.
speech.line: Commend me to your niece.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: I will, sweet queen.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: How now, where’s thy master? At my cousin Cressida’s?

speech.speaker: TRO. BOY.
speech.line: No, sir, he stays for you to conduct him thither.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Have you seen my cousin?

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: No, Pandarus, I stalk about her door,
Like to a strange soul upon the Stygian banks
Staying for waftage. O, be thou my Charon,
And give me swift transportance to these fields
Where I may wallow in the lily-beds
Propos’d for the deserver! O gentle Pandar,
From Cupid’s shoulder pluck his painted wings,
And fly with me to Cressid!

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Walk here i’ th’ orchard, I’ll bring her straight.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: She’s making her ready, she’ll come straight. You must be witty now: she does so blush, and fetches her wind so short, as if she were fray’d with a spirit. I’ll fetch her. It is the prettiest villain, she fetches her breath as short as a new-ta’en sparrow.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Come, come, what need you blush? Shame’s a baby. Here she is now, swear the oaths now to her that you have sworn to me.

What, are you gone again? You must be watch’d ere you be made tame, must you? Come your ways, come your ways; and you draw backward, we’ll put you i’ th’ fills. Why do you not speak to her? Come, draw this curtain, and let’s see your picture. Alas the day, how loath you are to offend daylight! And ’twere dark you’d close sooner. So, so, rub on and kiss the mistress. How now, a kiss in fee-farm? Build there, carpenter, the air is sweet. Nay, you shall fight your hearts out ere I part you—the falcon as the tercel, for all the ducks i’ th’ river. Go to, go to.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: You have bereft me of all words, lady.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Words pay no debts, give her deeds; but she’ll bereave you a’ th’ deeds too, if she call your activity in question. What, billing again? Here’s “In witness whereof the parties interchangeably”—Come in, come in, I’ll go get a fire.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: What, blushing still? Have you not done talking yet?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Well, uncle, what folly I commit, I dedicate to you.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: I thank you for that; if my lord get a boy of you, you’ll give him me. Be true to my lord; if he flinch, chide me for it.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: You know now your hostages: your uncle’s word and my firm faith.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Nay, I’ll give my word for her too. Our kindred, though they be long ere they be woo’d, they are constant being won. They are burs, I can tell you, they’ll stick where they are thrown.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Boldness comes to me now, and brings me heart.
Prince Troilus, I have lov’d you night and day
For many weary months.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Why was my Cressid then so hard to win?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Hard to seem won; but I was won, my lord,
With the first glance that ever—pardon me,
If I confess much, you will play the tyrant.
I love you now, but till now not so much
But I might master it. In faith I lie,
My thoughts were like unbridled children grown
Too headstrong for their mother. See, we fools!
Why have I blabb’d? Who shall be true to us,
When we are so unsecret to ourselves?
But though I lov’d you well, I woo’d you not,
And yet, good faith, I wish’d myself a man,
Or that we women had men’s privilege
Of speaking first. Sweet, bid me hold my tongue,
For in this rapture I shall surely speak
The thing I shall repent. See, see, your silence,
Cunning in dumbness, from my weakness draws
My very soul of counsel! Stop my mouth.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: And shall, albeit sweet music issues thence.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Pretty, i’ faith.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: My lord, I do beseech you pardon me,
’Twas not my purpose thus to beg a kiss.
I am asham’d. O heavens, what have I done!
For this time will I take my leave, my lord.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Your leave, sweet Cressid!

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Leave! And you take leave till tomorrow morning—

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Pray you content you.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: What offends you, lady?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Sir, mine own company.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: You cannot shun yourself.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Let me go and try.
I have a kind of self resides with you;
But an unkind self, that itself will leave
To be another’s fool. I would be gone.
Where is my wit? I know not what I speak.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Well know they what they speak that speak so wisely.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Perchance, my lord, I show more craft than love,
And fell so roundly to a large confession,
To angle for your thoughts, but you are wise,
Or else you love not; for to be wise and love
Exceeds man’s might; that dwells with gods above.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: O that I thought it could be in a woman—
As, if it can, I will presume in you—
To feed for aye her lamp and flames of love,
To keep her constancy in plight and youth,
Outliving beauties outward, with a mind
That doth renew swifter than blood decays!
Or that persuasion could but thus convince me
That my integrity and truth to you
Might be affronted with the match and weight
Of such a winnowed purity in love!
How were I then uplifted! But alas,
I am as true as truth’s simplicity,
And simpler than the infancy of truth.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: In that I’ll war with you.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: O virtuous fight,
When right with right wars who shall be most right!
True swains in love shall in the world to come
Approve their truth by Troilus. When their rhymes,
Full of protest, of oath and big compare,
Wants similes, truth tir’d with iteration,
As true as steel, as plantage to the moon,
As sun to day, as turtle to her mate,
As iron to adamant, as earth to th’ centre,
Yet after all comparisons of truth
(As truth’s authentic author to be cited)
“As true as Troilus” shall crown up the verse,
And sanctify the numbers.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Prophet may you be!
If I be false, or swerve a hair from truth,
When time is old and hath forgot itself,
When water-drops have worn the stones of Troy,
And blind oblivion swallow’d cities up,
And mighty states characterless are grated
To dusty nothing, yet let memory,
From false to false among false maids in love,
Upbraid my falsehood! When th’ have said as false
As air, as water, wind, or sandy earth,
As fox to lamb, or wolf to heifer’s calf,
Pard to the hind, or step-dame to her son,
Yea, let them say, to stick the heart of falsehood,
“As false as Cressid.”

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Go to, a bargain made, seal it, seal it, I’ll be the witness. Here I hold your hand, here my cousin’s. If ever you prove false one to another, since I have taken such pain to bring you together, let all pitiful goers-between be call’d to the world’s end after my name; call them all Pandars. Let all constant men be Troiluses, all false women Cressids, and all brokers-between Pandars! Say, amen.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Amen. Whereupon I will show you a chamber, which bed, because it shall not speak of your pretty encounters, press it to death. Away!

scene.scenelocation: The Grecian camp. Before Achilles’ tent.

stagedir.dir: Enter Ulysses, Diomedes, Nestor, Agamemnon, Ajax, Menelaus, and Calchas. Flourish.
Enter Achilles and Patroclus and stand in the door of their tent.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Good day, good day.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: How do you? How do you?

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: What mean these fellows? Know they not Achilles?

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: They pass by strangely. They were us’d to bend,
To send their smiles before them to Achilles,
To come as humbly as they us’d to creep
To holy altars.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: What, am I poor of late?
’Tis certain, greatness, once fall’n out with fortune,
Must fall out with men too. What the declin’d is,
He shall as soon read in the eyes of others
As feel in his own fall; for men, like butterflies,
Show not their mealy wings but to the summer,
And not a man, for being simply man,
Hath any honor, but honor for those honors
That are without him, as place, riches, and favor—
Prizes of accident as oft as merit,
Which when they fall, as being slippery standers,
The love that lean’d on them as slippery too,
Doth one pluck down another, and together
Die in the fall. But ’tis not so with me,
Fortune and I are friends. I do enjoy
At ample point all that I did possess,
Save these men’s looks, who do methinks find out
Some thing not worth in me such rich beholding
As they have often given. Here is Ulysses,
I’ll interrupt his reading.
How now, Ulysses?

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Now, great Thetis’ son!

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: What are you reading?

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: A strange fellow here
Writes me that man, how dearly ever parted,
How much in having, or without or in,
Cannot make boast to have that which he hath,
Nor feels not what he owes, but by reflection;
As when his virtues, aiming upon others,
Heat them, and they retort that heat again
To the first giver.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: This is not strange, Ulysses.
The beauty that is borne here in the face
The bearer knows not, but commends itself
To others’ eyes; nor doth the eye itself,
That most pure spirit of sense, behold itself,
Not going from itself; but eye to eye opposed,
Salutes each other with each other’s form;
For speculation turns not to itself,
Till it hath travell’d and is mirror’d there
Where it may see itself. This is not strange at all.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: I do not strain at the position—
It is familiar—but at the author’s drift,
Who in his circumstance expressly proves
That no man is the lord of any thing,
Though in and of him there be much consisting,
Till he communicate his parts to others;
Nor doth he of himself know them for aught,
Till he behold them formed in th’ applause
Where th’ are extended; who like an arch reverb’rate
The voice again, or like a gate of steel,
Fronting the sun, receives and renders back
His figure and his heat. I was much rapt in this,
And apprehended here immediately
Th’ unknown Ajax.
Heavens, what a man is there! A very horse,
That has he knows not what. Nature, what things there are
Most abject in regard, and dear in use!
What things again most dear in the esteem,
And poor in worth! Now shall we see tomorrow—
An act that very chance doth throw upon him—
Ajax renown’d! O heavens, what some men do,
While some men leave to do!
How some men creep in skittish Fortune’s hall,
Whiles others play the idiots in her eyes!
How one man eats into another’s pride,
While pride is fasting in his wantonness!
To see these Grecian lords!—why, even already
They clap the lubber Ajax on the shoulder,
As if his foot were on brave Hector’s breast,
And great Troy shrieking.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: I do believe it, for they pass’d by me
As misers do by beggars, neither gave to me
Good word nor look. What, are my deeds forgot?

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Time hath, my lord, a wallet at his back,
Wherein he puts alms for oblivion,
A great-siz’d monster of ingratitudes.
Those scraps are good deeds past, which are devour’d
As fast as they are made, forgot as soon
As done. Perseverance, dear my lord,
Keeps honor bright; to have done is to hang
Quite out of fashion, like a rusty mail
In monumental mock’ry. Take the instant way,
For honor travels in a strait so narrow,
Where one but goes abreast. Keep then the path,
For emulation hath a thousand sons
That one by one pursue. If you give way,
Or hedge aside from the direct forthright,
Like to an ent’red tide, they all rush by
And leave you hindmost;
Or like a gallant horse fall’n in first rank,
Lie there for pavement to the abject rear,
O’errun and trampled on. Then what they do in present,
Though less than yours in past, must o’ertop yours;
For Time is like a fashionable host
That slightly shakes his parting guest by th’ hand,
And with his arms outstretch’d as he would fly,
Grasps in the comer. The welcome ever smiles,
And farewell goes out sighing. Let not virtue seek
Remuneration for the thing it was;
For beauty, wit,
High birth, vigor of bone, desert in service,
Love, friendship, charity, are subjects all
To envious and calumniating Time.
One touch of nature makes the whole world kin,
That all with one consent praise new-born gawds,
Though they are made and moulded of things past,
And give to dust, that is a little gilt,
More laud than gilt o’erdusted.
The present eye praises the present object.
Then marvel not, thou great and complete man,
That all the Greeks begin to worship Ajax;
Since things in motion sooner catch the eye
Than what stirs not. The cry went once on thee,
And still it might, and yet it may again,
If thou wouldst not entomb thyself alive
And case thy reputation in thy tent,
Whose glorious deeds but in these fields of late
Made emulous missions ’mongst the gods themselves,
And drave great Mars to faction.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Of this my privacy
I have strong reasons.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: But ’gainst your privacy
The reasons are more potent and heroical.
’Tis known, Achilles, that you are in love
With one of Priam’s daughters.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Ha? Known?

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Is that a wonder?
The providence that’s in a watchful state
Knows almost every grain of Pluto’s gold,
Finds bottom in th’ uncomprehensive depth,
Keeps place with thought and almost, like the gods,
Do thoughts unveil in their dumb cradles.
There is a mystery (with whom relation
Durst never meddle) in the soul of state,
Which hath an operation more divine
Than breath or pen can give expressure to.
All the commerce that you have had with Troy
As perfectly is ours as yours, my lord,
And better would it fit Achilles much
To throw down Hector than Polyxena.
But it must grieve young Pyrrhus now at home,
When fame shall in our islands sound her trump,
And all the Greekish girls shall tripping sing,
“Great Hector’s sister did Achilles win,
But our great Ajax bravely beat down him.”
Farewell, my lord; I as your lover speak:
The fool slides o’er the ice that you should break.

scene.line: A labor sav’d!

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: A wonder!

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Ajax goes up and down the field, asking for himself.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: How so?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: He must fight singly tomorrow with Hector, and is so prophetically proud of an heroical cudgelling that he raves in saying nothing.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: How can that be?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Why, ’a stalks up and down like a peacock—a stride and a stand; ruminates like an hostess that hath no arithmetic but her brain to set down her reckoning; bites his lip with a politic regard, as who should say there were wit in this head and ’twould out—and so there is; but it lies as coldly in him as fire in a flint, which will not show without knocking. The man’s undone forever, for if Hector break not his neck i’ th’ combat, he’ll break’t himself in vainglory. He knows not me. I said, “Good morrow, Ajax”; and he replies, “Thanks, Agamemnon.” What think you of this man that takes me for the general? He’s grown a very land-fish, languageless, a monster. A plague of opinion! A man may wear it on both sides, like a leather jerkin.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Thou must be my ambassador to him, Thersites.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Who, I? Why, he’ll answer nobody; he professes not answering. Speaking is for beggars; he wears his tongue in ’s arms. I will put on his presence, let Patroclus make demands to me; you shall see the pageant of Ajax.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: To him, Patroclus. Tell him I humbly desire the valiant Ajax to invite the most valorous Hector to come unarm’d to my tent, and to procure safe-conduct for his person of the magnanimous and most illustrious six-or-seven-times-honor’d captain-general of the army, Agamemnon, et cetera. Do this.

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: Jove bless great Ajax!

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Hum?

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: I come from the worthy Achilles—

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Ha?

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: Who most humbly desires you to invite Hector to his tent—

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Hum?

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: And to procure safe-conduct from Agamemnon.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Agamemnon?

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: Ay, my lord.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Ha?

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: What say you to’t?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: God buy you, with all my heart.

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: Your answer, sir.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: If tomorrow be a fair day, by aleven of the clock it will go one way or other. Howsoever, he shall pay for me ere he has me.

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: Your answer, sir.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Fare ye well, with all my heart.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Why, but he is not in this tune, is he?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: No; but he’s out of tune thus. What music will be in him when Hector has knock’d out his brains, I know not; but I am sure none, unless the fiddler Apollo get his sinews to make catlings on.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Come, thou shalt bear a letter to him straight.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Let me bear another to his horse, for that’s the more capable creature.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: My mind is troubled, like a fountain stirr’d,
And I myself see not the bottom of it.

stagedir.dir: Enter at one door Aeneas with a torch; at another, Paris, Deiphobus, Antenor, Diomedes the Grecian, and others with torches.

speech.speaker: PAR.
speech.line: And tell me, noble Diomed—faith, tell me true,
Even in soul of sound good-fellowship—
Who, in your thoughts, deserves fair Helen best,
Myself, or Menelaus?

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: Both alike.
He merits well to have her that doth seek her,
Not making any scruple of her soil,
With such a hell of pain and world of charge;
And you as well to keep her that defend her,
Not palating the taste of her dishonor,
With such a costly loss of wealth and friends.
He like a puling cuckold would drink up
The lees and dregs of a flat tamed piece;
You like a lecher out of whorish loins
Are pleas’d to breed out your inheritors.
Both merits pois’d, each weighs nor less nor more,
But he as he, the heavier for a whore.

speech.speaker: PAR.
speech.line: You are too bitter to your country-woman.

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: She’s bitter to her country. Hear me, Paris:
For every false drop in her bawdy veins,
A Grecian’s life hath sunk; for every scruple
Of her contaminated carrion weight,
A Troyan hath been slain. Since she could speak,
She hath not given so many good words breath
As for her Greeks and Troyans suff’red death.

speech.speaker: PAR.
speech.line: Fair Diomed, you do as chapmen do,
Dispraise the thing that they desire to buy,
But we in silence hold this virtue well,
We’ll not commend what we intend to sell.
Here lies our way.

scene.scenelocation: Troy. A court before Pandarus’s house.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: A pestilence on him! Now will he be mocking.
I shall have such a life!

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: How now, how now, how go maidenheads?
Here, you maid! Where’s my cousin Cressid?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Go hang yourself, you naughty mocking uncle!
You bring me to do—and then you flout me too.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: To do what, to do what? Let her say what.
What have I brought you to do?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Come, come, beshrew your heart, you’ll ne’er be good,
Nor suffer others.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Ha, ha! Alas, poor wretch! A poor capocchia! Hast not slept tonight? Would he not, a naughty man, let it sleep? A bugbear take him!

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Did not I tell you? Would he were knock’d i’ th’ head!
How earnestly they knock! Pray you come in.
I would not for half Troy have you seen here.

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: Good morrow, lord, good morrow.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Who’s there? My Lord Aeneas! By my troth,
I knew you not. What news with you so early?

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: Is not Prince Troilus here?

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Here? What should he do here?

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: Come, he is here, my lord, do not deny him. It doth import him much to speak with me.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Is he here, say you? It’s more than I know, I’ll be sworn. For my own part, I came in late. What should he do here?

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: Who!—nay then. Come, come, you’ll do him wrong ere you are ware. You’ll be so true to him, to be false to him. Do not you know of him, but yet go fetch him hither, go.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Is’t possible? No sooner got but lost? The devil take Antenor! The young prince will go mad. A plague upon Antenor! I would they had broke ’s neck!

speech.speaker: PAR.
speech.line: It is great morning, and the hour prefix’d
For her delivery to this valiant Greek
Comes fast upon. Good my brother Troilus,
Tell you the lady what she is to do,
And haste her to the purpose.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Walk into her house.
I’ll bring her to the Grecian presently;
And to his hand when I deliver her,
Think it an altar, and thy brother Troilus
A priest there off’ring to it his own heart.

speech.speaker: PAN.
speech.line: Be moderate, be moderate.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Why tell you me of moderation?
The grief is fine, full, perfect, that I taste,
And violenteth in a sense as strong
As that which causeth it. How can I moderate it?
If I could temporize with my affections,
Or brew it to a weak and colder palate,
The like allayment could I give my grief:
My love admits no qualifying dross,
No more my grief, in such a precious loss.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: I must then to the Grecians?

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: No remedy.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: A woeful Cressid ’mongst the merry Greeks!
When shall we see again?

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Hear me, love. Be thou but true of heart—

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: I true? How now? What wicked deem is this?

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Nay, we must use expostulation kindly,
For it is parting from us.
I speak not “be thou true” as fearing thee,
For I will throw my glove to Death himself
That there is no maculation in thy heart;
But “be thou true” say I to fashion in
My sequent protestation: be thou true,
And I will see thee.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: O, you shall be expos’d, my lord, to dangers
As infinite as imminent! But I’ll be true.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: And I’ll grow friend with danger. Wear this sleeve.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: And you this glove. When shall I see you?

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: I will corrupt the Grecian sentinels,
To give thee nightly visitation.
But yet be true.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: O heavens, “be true” again?

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Hear why I speak it, love.
The Grecian youths are full of quality;
Their loving well compos’d with gift of nature,
Flowing and swelling o’er with arts and exercise.
How novelty may move, and parts with person,
Alas, a kind of godly jealousy
(Which I beseech you call a virtuous sin)
Makes me afeard.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: O heavens, you love me not.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Die I a villain then!
In this I do not call your faith in question
So mainly as my merit. I cannot sing,
Nor heel the high lavolt, nor sweeten talk,
Nor play at subtle games—fair virtues all,
To which the Grecians are most prompt and pregnant—
But I can tell that in each grace of these
There lurks a still and dumb-discoursive devil
That tempts most cunningly, but be not tempted.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Do you think I will?

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: No,
But something may be done that we will not,
And sometimes we are devils to ourselves,
When we will tempt the frailty of our powers,
Presuming on their changeful potency.

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: Nay, good my lord!

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Come kiss, and let us part.

speech.speaker: PAR.
speech.line: Brother Troilus!

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Good brother, come you hither,
And bring Aeneas and the Grecian with you.

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: My lord, will you be true?

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Who, I? Alas, it is my vice, my fault:
Whiles others fish with craft for great opinion,
I with great truth catch mere simplicity;
Whilst some with cunning gild their copper crowns,
With truth and plainness I do wear mine bare.
Fear not my truth: the moral of my wit
Is “plain and true”; there’s all the reach of it.

stagedir.dir: Enter Aeneas, Paris, Antenor, Deiphobus, and Diomedes.

speech.speaker: PAR.
speech.line: Hark, Hector’s trumpet!

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: How have we spent this morning!
The Prince must think me tardy and remiss,
That swore to ride before him to the field.

speech.speaker: PAR.
speech.line: ’Tis Troilus’ fault. Come, come, to field with him.

speech.speaker: DEI.
speech.line: Let us make ready straight.

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: Yea, with a bridegroom’s fresh alacrity
Let us address to tend on Hector’s heels.
The glory of our Troy doth this day lie
On his fair worth and single chivalry.

stagedir.dir: Enter Ajax armed, Achilles, Patroclus, Agamemnon, Menelaus, Ulysses, Nestor, Greek Trumpeter, etc.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: No trumpet answers.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: ’Tis but early days.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: A woman of quick sense.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Fie, fie upon her!
There’s language in her eye, her cheek, her lip,
Nay, her foot speaks; her wanton spirits look out
At every joint and motive of her body.
O, these encounterers, so glib of tongue,
That give a coasting welcome ere it comes,
And wide unclasp the tables of their thoughts
To every ticklish reader! Set them down
For sluttish spoils of opportunity,
And daughters of the game.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: The Troyans’ trumpet.

stagedir.dir: Enter all of Troy: Hector armed, Paris, Aeneas, Helenus, Troilus, and Attendants.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: Here is Sir Diomed. Go, gentle knight,
Stand by our Ajax. As you and Lord Aeneas
Consent upon the order of their fight,
So be it, either to the uttermost,
Or else a breath. The combatants being kin
Half stints their strife before their strokes begin.

stagedir.dir: Ajax and Hector enter the lists.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: They are oppos’d already.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: What Troyan is that same that looks so heavy?

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: The youngest son of Priam, a true knight,
Not yet mature, yet matchless, firm of word,
Speaking in deeds, and deedless in his tongue,
Not soon provok’d, nor being provok’d soon calm’d;
His heart and hand both open and both free,
For what he has he gives, what thinks he shows,
Yet gives he not till judgment guide his bounty,
Nor dignifies an impare thought with breath;
Manly as Hector, but more dangerous,
For Hector in his blaze of wrath subscribes
To tender objects, but he in heat of action
Is more vindicative than jealous love.
They call him Troilus, and on him erect
A second hope, as fairly built as Hector.
Thus says Aeneas, one that knows the youth
Even to his inches, and with private soul
Did in great Ilion thus translate him to me.

scene.line: My well-fam’d lord of Troy, no less to you.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Let me confirm my princely brother’s greeting:
You brace of warlike brothers, welcome hither.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Who must we answer?

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: The noble Menelaus.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: O, you, my lord? By Mars his gauntlet, thanks!
Mock not that I affect th’ untraded oath,
Your quondam wife swears still by Venus’ glove.
She’s well, but bade me not commend her to you.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Name her not now, sir, she’s a deadly theme.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: O, pardon, I offend.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: I have, thou gallant Troyan, seen thee oft,
Laboring for destiny, make cruel way
Through ranks of Greekish youth, and I have seen thee,
As hot as Perseus, spur thy Phrygian steed,
Despising many forfeits and subduements,
When thou hast hung thy advanced sword i’ th’ air,
Not letting it decline on the declined,
That I have said to some my standers-by
“Lo Jupiter is yonder, dealing life!”
And I have seen thee pause and take thy breath,
When that a ring of Greeks have hemm’d thee in,
Like an Olympian wrastling. This have I seen,
But this thy countenance, still lock’d in steel,
I never saw till now. I knew thy grandsire,
And once fought with him. He was a soldier good,
But, by great Mars, the captain of us all,
Never like thee. O, let an old man embrace thee,
And, worthy warrior, welcome to our tents.

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: ’Tis the old Nestor.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Let me embrace thee, good old chronicle,
That hast so long walk’d hand in hand with time.
Most reverend Nestor, I am glad to clasp thee.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: I would my arms could match thee in contention,
As they contend with thee in courtesy.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: I would they could.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: Ha!
By this white beard, I’d fight with thee tomorrow.
Well, welcome, welcome!—I have seen the time.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: I wonder now how yonder city stands
When we have here her base and pillar by us.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: I know your favor, Lord Ulysses, well.
Ah, sir, there’s many a Greek and Troyan dead
Since first I saw yourself and Diomed
In Ilion, on your Greekish embassy.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Sir, I foretold you then what would ensue.
My prophecy is but half his journey yet,
For yonder walls that pertly front your town,
Yon towers, whose wanton tops do buss the clouds,
Must kiss their own feet.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: I must not believe you.
There they stand yet, and modestly I think
The fall of every Phrygian stone will cost
A drop of Grecian blood. The end crowns all,
And that old common arbitrator, Time,
Will one day end it.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: So to him we leave it.
Most gentle and most valiant Hector, welcome!
After the general, I beseech you next
To feast with me and see me at my tent.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: I shall forestall thee, Lord Ulysses, thou!
Now, Hector, I have fed mine eyes on thee;
I have with exact view perus’d thee, Hector,
And quoted joint by joint.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Is this Achilles?

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: I am Achilles.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Stand fair, I pray thee, let me look on thee.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Behold thy fill.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Nay, I have done already.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Thou art too brief. I will the second time,
As I would buy thee, view thee limb by limb.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: O, like a book of sport thou’lt read me o’er;
But there’s more in me than thou understand’st.
Why dost thou so oppress me with thine eye?

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Tell me, you heavens, in which part of his body
Shall I destroy him—whether there, or there, or there?—
That I may give the local wound a name,
And make distinct the very breach whereout
Hector’s great spirit flew. Answer me, heavens!

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: It would discredit the blest gods, proud man,
To answer such a question. Stand again.
Think’st thou to catch my life so pleasantly
As to prenominate in nice conjecture
Where thou wilt hit me dead?

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: I tell thee, yea.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Wert thou an oracle to tell me so,
I’d not believe thee. Henceforth guard thee well,
For I’ll not kill thee there, nor there, nor there,
But by the forge that stithied Mars his helm,
I’ll kill thee every where, yea, o’er and o’er.
You wisest Grecians, pardon me this brag.
His insolence draws folly from my lips,
But I’ll endeavor deeds to match these words,
Or may I never—

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: Do not chafe thee, cousin,
And you, Achilles, let these threats alone,
Till accident or purpose bring you to’t.
You may have every day enough of Hector,
If you have stomach. The general state, I fear,
Can scarce entreat you to be odd with him.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: I pray you let us see you in the field;
We have had pelting wars since you refus’d
The Grecians’ cause.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Dost thou entreat me, Hector?
Tomorrow do I meet thee, fell as death;
Tonight all friends.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Thy hand upon that match.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: First, all you peers of Greece, go to my tent;
There in the full convive we. Afterwards,
As Hector’s leisure and your bounties shall
Concur together, severally entreat him.
Beat loud the taborins, let the trumpets blow,
That this great soldier may his welcome know.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all but Troilus and Ulysses.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: I’ll heat his blood with Greekish wine tonight,
Which with my scimitar I’ll cool tomorrow.
Patroclus, let us feast him to the height.

speech.speaker: PATR.
speech.line: Here comes Thersites.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: With too much blood and too little brain, these two may run mad, but, if with too much brain and too little blood they do, I’ll be a curer of madmen. Here’s Agamemnon, an honest fellow enough, and one that loves quails, but he has not so much brain as ear-wax; and the goodly transformation of Jupiter there, his brother, the bull, the primitive statue and oblique memorial of cuckolds, a thrifty shoeing-horn in a chain, hanging at his brother’s leg—to what form but that he is, should wit larded with malice, and malice fac’d with wit, turn him to? To an ass, were nothing, he is both ass and ox; to an ox, were nothing, he is both ox and ass. To be a dog, a moile, a cat, a fitchook, a toad, a lezard, an owl, a puttock, or a herring without a roe, I would not care; but to be Menelaus, I would conspire against destiny. Ask me not what I would be if I were not Thersites, for I care not to be the louse of a lazar, so I were not Menelaus. Hey-day! Sprites and fires!

stagedir.dir: Enter Agamemnon, Hector, Troilus, Ajax, Ulysses, Nestor, Menelaus, and Diomedes, with lights.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: Here comes himself to guide you.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Welcome, brave Hector, welcome, princes all.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: So now, fair Prince of Troy, I bid good night.
Ajax commands the guard to tend on you.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Thanks and good night to the Greeks’ general.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Good night, my lord.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Good night, sweet Lord Menelaus.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Sweet draught! “Sweet,” quoth ’a! Sweet sink, sweet sewer.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Good night and welcome, both at once, to those
That go or tarry.

speech.speaker: AGAM.
speech.line: Good night.

scene.line: Follow his torch, he goes to Calchas’ tent.
I’ll keep you company.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Sweet sir, you honor me.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: And so good night.

stagedir.dir: Exit Diomedes, Ulysses and Troilus following.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: That same Diomed’s a false-hearted rogue, a most unjust knave. I will no more trust him when he leers than I will a serpent when he hisses. He will spend his mouth and promise, like Brabbler the hound, but when he performs, astronomers foretell it: it is prodigious, there will come some change; the sun borrows of the moon when Diomed keeps his word. I will rather leave to see Hector than not to dog him. They say he keeps a Troyan drab, and uses the traitor Calchas’ tent. I’ll after—nothing but lechery! All incontinent varlots!

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: What, are you up here, ho? Speak!

speech.speaker: CAL.
speech.line: Who calls?

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: Diomed. Calchas, I think. Where’s your daughter?

speech.speaker: CAL.
speech.line: She comes to you.

stagedir.dir: Enter Troilus and Ulysses at a distance; after them, Thersites.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Cressid comes forth to him.

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: How now, my charge?

speech.speaker: CRES.
speech.line: Now, my sweet guardian, hark, a word with you.

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: You have sworn patience.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Fear me not, my lord.
I will not be myself, nor have cognition
Of what I feel; I am all patience.

scene.line: Troilus, farewell! One eye yet looks on thee,
But with my heart the other eye doth see.
Ah, poor our sex! This fault in us I find,
The error of our eye directs our mind.
What error leads must err; O then conclude,
Minds sway’d by eyes are full of turpitude.

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: I have been seeking you this hour, my lord.
Hector by this is arming him in Troy;
Ajax, your guard, stays to conduct you home.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Have with you, Prince. My courteous lord, adieu.
Farewell, revolted fair! And, Diomed,
Stand fast, and wear a castle on thy head!

speech.speaker: ULYSS.
speech.line: I’ll bring you to the gates.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Accept distracted thanks.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Where is my brother Hector?

speech.speaker: AND.
speech.line: Here, sister, arm’d, and bloody in intent.
Consort with me in loud and dear petition,
Pursue we him on knees; for I have dreamt
Of bloody turbulence, and this whole night
Hath nothing been but shapes and forms of slaughter.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: O, ’tis true.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Ho! Bid my trumpet sound!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: No notes of sally, for the heavens, sweet brother.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Be gone, I say, the gods have heard me swear.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: The gods are deaf to hot and peevish vows;
They are polluted off’rings, more abhorr’d
Than spotted livers in the sacrifice.

speech.speaker: AND.
speech.line: O, be persuaded! Do not count it holy
To hurt by being just; it is as lawful,
For we would give much, to use violent thefts,
And rob in the behalf of charity.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: It is the purpose that makes strong the vow,
But vows to every purpose must not hold;
Unarm, sweet Hector.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Hold you still, I say;
Mine honor keeps the weather of my fate.
Life every man holds dear, but the dear man
Holds honor far more precious-dear than life.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: No, faith, young Troilus, doff thy harness, youth,
I am today i’ th’ vein of chivalry.
Let grow thy sinews till their knots be strong,
And tempt not yet the brushes of the war.
Unarm thee, go, and doubt thou not, brave boy,
I’ll stand today for thee and me and Troy.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Brother, you have a vice of mercy in you,
Which better fits a lion than a man.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: What vice is that? Good Troilus, chide me for it.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: When many times the captive Grecian falls,
Even in the fan and wind of your fair sword,
You bid them rise and live.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: O, ’tis fair play.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Fool’s play, by heaven, Hector.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: How now? How now?

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: For th’ love of all the gods,
Let’s leave the hermit pity with our mother,
And when we have our armors buckled on,
The venom’d vengeance ride upon our swords,
Spur them to ruthful work, rein them from ruth.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Fie, savage, fie!

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Hector, then ’tis wars.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Troilus, I would not have you fight today.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Who should withhold me?
Not fate, obedience, nor the hand of Mars
Beck’ning with fiery truncheon my retire,
Not Priamus and Hecuba on knees,
Their eyes o’ergalled with recourse of tears,
Nor you, my brother, with your true sword drawn,
Oppos’d to hinder me, should stop my way,
But by my ruin.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: This foolish, dreaming, superstitious girl
Makes all these bodements.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: O, farewell, dear Hector.
Look how thou diest, look how thy eye turns pale.
Look how thy wounds do bleed at many vents,
Hark how Troy roars, how Hecuba cries out,
How poor Andromache shrills her dolors forth.
Behold, distraction, frenzy, and amazement,
Like witless antics, one another meet,
And all cry, Hector! Hector’s dead! O Hector!

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Away, away.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Farewell; yet soft: Hector, I take my leave.
Thou dost thyself and all our Troy deceive.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: They are at it, hark! Proud Diomed, believe,
I come to lose my arm, or win my sleeve.

scene.scenelocation: The plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.
scene.line: Soft, here comes sleeve and t’ other.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Fly not, for shouldst thou take the river Styx,
I would swim after.

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: Thou dost miscall retire.
I do not fly, but advantageous care
Withdrew me from the odds of multitude.
Have at thee!

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: Hold thy whore, Grecian!—now for thy whore, Troyan!—now the sleeve, now the sleeve!

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: What art thou, Greek? Art thou for Hector’s match?
Art thou of blood and honor?

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: No, no, I am a rascal, a scurvy railing knave, a very filthy rogue.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: I do believe thee, live.

speech.speaker: NEST.
speech.line: Go bear Patroclus’ body to Achilles,
And bid the snail-pac’d Ajax arm for shame.
There is a thousand Hectors in the field:
Now here he fights on Galathe his horse,
And there lacks work; anon he’s there afoot,
And there they fly or die, like scaling sculls
Before the belching whale; then is he yonder,
And there the strawy Greeks, ripe for his edge,
Fall down before him like a mower’s swath.
Here, there, and every where, he leaves and takes,
Dexterity so obeying appetite
That what he will he does, and does so much
That proof is call’d impossibility.

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: Troilus, thou coward Troilus!

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: Troilus, thou coward Troilus, show thy head!

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: O traitor Diomed! Turn thy false face, thou traitor,
And pay thy life thou owest me for my horse.

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: Ha, art thou there?

speech.speaker: AJAX.
speech.line: I’ll fight with him alone. Stand, Diomed.

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: He is my prize, I will not look upon.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Come both you cogging Greeks, have at you both!

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Yea, Troilus? O, well fought, my youngest brother!

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Pause if thou wilt.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: I do disdain thy courtesy, proud Troyan.
Be happy that my arms are out of use;
My rest and negligence befriends thee now,
But thou anon shalt hear of me again;
Till when, go seek thy fortune.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Ajax hath ta’en Aeneas! Shall it be?
No, by the flame of yonder glorious heaven,
He shall not carry him; I’ll be ta’en too,
Or bring him off. Fate, hear me what I say!
I reck not though I end my life today.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: Stand, stand, thou Greek, thou art a goodly mark.
No? Wilt thou not? I like thy armor well;
I’ll frush it and unlock the rivets all,
But I’ll be master of it.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: The cuckold and the cuckold-maker are at it. Now, bull! Now, dog! ’Loo, Paris, ’loo! Now my double-henn’d Spartan! ’Loo, Paris, ’loo! The bull has the game, ware horns ho!

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Turn, slave, and fight.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: What art thou?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: A bastard son of Priam’s.

speech.speaker: THER.
speech.line: I am a bastard too, I love bastards. I am bastard begot, bastard instructed, bastard in mind, bastard in valor, in every thing illegitimate. One bear will not bite another, and wherefore should one bastard? Take heed, the quarrel’s most ominous to us. If the son of a whore fight for a whore, he tempts judgment. Farewell, bastard.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Look, Hector, how the sun begins to set,
How ugly night comes breathing at his heels;
Even with the vail and dark’ning of the sun,
To close the day up, Hector’s life is done.

speech.speaker: HECT.
speech.line: I am unarm’d, forgo this vantage, Greek.

speech.speaker: ACHIL.
speech.line: Strike, fellows, strike, this is the man I seek.

stagedir.dir: Sound retreat. Shout. Enter Agamemnon, Ajax, Menelaus, Nestor, Diomedes, and the rest, marching.

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: Stand ho! Yet are we masters of the field.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: Never go home, here starve we out the night—
Hector is slain.

speaker.long: All Aeneas, Paris, Antenor, and Deiphobus

speech.speaker: ALL AENE., PAR., DEI., ANT.
speech.line: Hector! The gods forbid!

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: He’s dead, and at the murderer’s horse’s tail,
In beastly sort, dragg’d through the shameful field.
Frown on, you heavens, effect your rage with speed!
Sit, gods, upon your thrones, and smile at Troy!
I say at once, let your brief plagues be mercy,
And linger not our sure destructions on!

speech.speaker: AENE.
speech.line: My lord, you do discomfort all the host.

speech.speaker: TRO.
speech.line: You understand me not that tell me so.
I do not speak of flight, of fear, of death,
But dare all imminence that gods and men
Address their dangers in. Hector is gone.
Who shall tell Priam so, or Hecuba?
Let him that will a screech owl aye be call’d
Go in to Troy and say there, “Hector’s dead!”
There is a word will Priam turn to stone,
Make wells and Niobes of the maids and wives,
Cold statues of the youth, and in a word,
Scare Troy out of itself. But march away.
Hector is dead; there is no more to say.
Stay yet. You vile abominable tents,
Thus proudly pight upon our Phrygian plains,
Let Titan rise as early as he dare,
I’ll through and through you! And, thou great-siz’d coward,
No space of earth shall sunder our two hates.
I’ll haunt thee like a wicked conscience still,
That mouldeth goblins swift as frenzy’s thoughts.
Strike a free march. To Troy with comfort go;
Hope of revenge shall hide our inward woe.

scene.line: Ignominy, shame
Pursue thy life, and live aye with thy name!
